Records|Warner Bros.]]|Edge Music Nashville|[[Average Joe's Entertainment]]}} | website = {{URL|www.therealbigsmo.com/}} }} '''John Smith''' (born February 14, 1976), known by his stage name '''Big Smo''', is an American [[country rap]] musician, singer, songwriter, [[record producer]] and film director. After several independent and minor label releases, Smo's [[record label|major label]] debut studio album, ''[[Kuntry Livin']]'', was released in 2014 and charted on three ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' charts. He was the subject of an eponymous reality television series on [[A&E (TV channel)|A&E]] that began in 2014. ==Early life== John Lee Smith was born in San Diego, California, to mother Mary Jane Smith and father Carl Avery Smith.{{cite web|url=http://www.lyrics.net/lyric/30813515|title=Workin' Lyrics|publisher=Lyrics.net|accessdate=June 23, 2014}}{{cite web |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/big-smo-mn0000868733/biography |title=Big Smo | Biography|last=Leggett|first=Steve|publisher=[[AllMusic]]|accessdate=June 23, 2014}} His father, who was a [[veteran]] of the [[U.S. Navy]], died in 2007.{{cite web|url=http://www.t-g.com/story/1220441.html|title=Edgemont Baptist to mark Independence Day|last=Dezotell|first=Doug|date=June 29, 2007|work=Shelbyville Times-Gazette|accessdate=June 23, 2014}} His mother is his business manager.{{cite web|url=http://www.t-g.com/story/2088917.html|title=Rapping on fame's door|last=Mosley|first=Brian|date=June 4, 2014|work=Shelbyville Times-Gazette|accessdate=June 23, 2014}}[http://www.aetv.com/big-smo/exclusives/20-things-you-need-to-know-about-big-smo 20 Things You Need to Know About Big Smo] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140713041420/http://www.aetv.com/big-smo/exclusives/20-things-you-need-to-know-about-big-smo |date=July 13, 2014 }}. A&E Channel. Retrieved July 18, 2014. ==Music career== Smith started his musical endeavors in 1999, but did not release an album for three years.{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/big-smo-mn0000868733/discography|title=Big Smo | Discography|publisher=AllMusic|accessdate=June 23, 2014}} He released ''Kuntry Kitchen'' with Yayoda Records in 2002. Then, he released another album with Yayoda in 2007 entitled ''The True South''. His last self-released album was 2018's ''Special Reserve''{{failed verification|date=February 2018}} In 2010, his homemade music video "Kickin' It in Tennessee" went viral, garnering over five million views on YouTube.{{cite web|last1=Mosely|first1=Brian|title=Big Smo hits big time|url=http://www.t-g.com/story/2083444.html|website=Shelbyville Times-Gazette|publisher=Hugh Jones|accessdate=June 23, 2014|date=May 16, 2014|archive-date=August 9, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140809041006/http://www.t-g.com/story/2083444.html|url-status=dead}} He released two [[extended plays|EPs]] with [[Warner Bros. Records]] that were 2012's ''Grass Roots'' and 2013's ''Backwoods Whiskey''. Smith's major-label debut came out in 2014, entitled ''[[Kuntry Livin']]''. ==Musical style== According to Matt Bjorke of Roughstock, Big Smo is one of the foremost grassroots artists in a style known as [[rural rap]] or hick-hop, "which blends rural, Country themes and melodies with some rap elements (production and vocal delivery)".{{cite web|url=http://www.roughstock.com/reviews/album-review-big-smo-kuntry-livin|title=Album Review: Big Smo - Kuntry Livin'|last=Bjorke|first=Matt|date=June 3, 2014|publisher=Roughstock|accessdate=June 24, 2014|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140618220017/http://www.roughstock.com/reviews/album-review-big-smo-kuntry-livin|archivedate=June 18, 2014}} [[AllMusic]]'s Steve Legget commented that Big Smo "combines country themes and attitudes with rap and hip-hop in a style that prompted one reviewer to note 'If Kid Rock and Run–D.M.C. had a love child, he would be named Big Smo,' although combining Hank Williams Jr. with Nappy Roots might strike a bit closer." ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' described Big Smo as sounding like "If Run–D.M.C.'s 'Walk This Way' stomped out of Queens and ended up in the rural south."{{cite magazine|title=10 New Artists You Need to Know: June 2014|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/pictures/10-new-artists-you-need-to-know-june-2014-20140619/big-smo-0538353|last=Murray|first=Nick|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|accessdate=June 24, 2014|date=June 19, 2014}} The music on ''Kuntry Livin''' was described as spinning "rap rhymes about working-class values over hard-rock riffs."{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/music/2014/06/02/echo-bunnymen-big-smo-lp/9884569/|title=Listen Up: Other notable releases|last=Mansfield|first=Brian|authorlink=Brian Mansfield|date=June 3, 2014|work=USA Today|accessdate=June 24, 2014}} ==Other media== Smith was the principal subject of an [[:wikt:eponym|eponym]]ously titled television series, ''Big Smo''. The program, about his life and music by [[A&E (TV channel)|A&E]], debuted in June 2014.{{cite news| author = Sara Bibel| title =New Series 'Big Smo' to Premiere Wednesday, June 11 on A&E| newspaper =[[TV by the Numbers]], [[Zap2it]]| date =May 13, 2014| url =http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2014/05/13/new-series-big-smo-to-premiere-wednesday-june-11-on-ae/264028/| archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20140514073433/http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2014/05/13/new-series-big-smo-to-premiere-wednesday-june-11-on-ae/264028/| url-status =dead| archive-date =May 14, 2014| accessdate = July 17, 2015}} He appeared in one episode, "Empty Bottles Full Cans", of the [[Spike (TV network)|Spike]] TV series ''[[Bar Rescue]]''.{{cite news| author =Mary-Kate Dunphy| title =M T Bottle is About to Get Canned by Taffer| newspaper = Nightclub & Bar Magazine| date =November 10, 2013| url =http://www.nightclub.com/bar-rescue/bar-rescue/m-t-bottle-about-get-canned-taffer| accessdate = July 17, 2015}} His life is featured in episode one, "Kuntry Livin", of CarbonTV's original series ''Heartlandia'', showing him shooting guns, cooking, and making music.{{cite web|url=http://www.carbontv.com/shows/heartlandia/episodes/1/|title=SMO - Kuntry Livin' : Heartlandia|accessdate=February 2, 2017}} ==Personal life== Smith lives on his {{convert|32|acre}} family farm compound known as, the "Kuntry Ranch", located in [[Unionville, Tennessee]], a part of the [[Shelbyville, Tennessee]] Micropolitan Statistical Area.{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/big-smo/biography/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130725184733/http://www.cmt.com/artists/big-smo/biography/|url-status=dead|archive-date=July 25, 2013|title=About Big Smo|publisher=Country Music Television|accessdate=June 23, 2014}} In 2024, after losing 225 pounds, he announced plans to open a plant-based food truck in Shelbyville.{{cite web|url=https://www.newschannel5.com/news/country-rapper-smo-to-open-plant-based-food-truck-in-shelbyville|title=Country rapper Smo to open plant-based food truck in Shelbyville|date=February 23, 2024 |publisher=WTVF-TV, Nashville, TN|accessdate=February 27, 2024}} ==Discography== ===Studio albums=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |+ List of studio albums, with selected chart positions ! scope="col" rowspan="2" style="width:16em;" | Title ! scope="col" rowspan="2" style="width:20em;" | Album details ! scope="col" colspan="3" | Peak chart positions |- |- !style="width:3em; font-size:90%"|[[Billboard 200|US]]{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/big-smo/chart-history/tlp/|title=Big Smo Chart History|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |accessdate=June 1, 2018}}{{fv|date=April 2023|reason=No titles at this reference; is this still a viable link?}} !style="width:3em; font-size:90%"|[[Top Country Albums|US
